PHY472.name: Quantum Physics II

PHY480.name: Computational Physics

PHY481.name: Electricity and Magnetism I
PHY481.description: Electrostatics, dielectrics, magnetic fields of steady state currents, Faraday law of induction.
PHY481.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

PHY482.name: Electricity and Magnetism II
PHY482.description: Maxwell's equations, scalar and vector potentials, electromagnetic plane waves.
PHY482.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students.

PHY491.name: Introduction to Condensed Matter Physics
PHY491.description: Many-electron atoms. Molecules, crystal structure, lattice dynamics. Band models of metals and semiconductors, transport properties.

PHY492.name: Introduction to Nuclear Physics
PHY492.description: Survey of phenomena and conceptual foundations of nuclear physics.
PHY492.prerequisite: (PHY 471) and completion of Tier I writing requirement

PHY493.name: Introduction to Elementary Particle Physics
PHY493.description: Introduction to concepts and theory for elementary particle physics.
PHY493.prerequisite: (PHY 471) and completion of Tier I writing requirement
PHY493.restrictions: Open to undergraduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy or approval of department.

PHY800.name: Research Methods
PHY800.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PHY800.description: Design and setup of experiments in various faculty research areas. Data collection and analysis. Study and practice of theoretical methods.

PHY801.name: Survey of Atomic and Condensed Matter Physics
PHY801.description: Survey of physics phenomena related to atomic, liquid and solid systems. Describe underlying microscopic principles responsible for properties of matter.
PHY801.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy or approval of department.

PHY802.name: Survey of Nuclear Physics
PHY802.description: Survey of phenomena and conceptual foundations of nuclear physics.
PHY802.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy or approval of department.

PHY803.name: Survey of Elementary Particle Physics
PHY803.description: Overview of high-energy physics, including the standard model, quark composition of hadrons, collider physics and the role of elementary particle physics in cosmology.
PHY803.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy or approval of department.

PHY810.name: Methods of Theoretical Physics
PHY810.description: Theoretical methods used in classical mechanics, quantum mechanics, electrodynamics, and statistical mechanics.

PHY812.name: Advanced Methods of Theoretical Physics
PHY812.description: Advanced mathematical tools for theoretical physics. Group theory, advanced Green's functions and asymptotic methods.

PHY820.name: Classical Mechanics
PHY820.description: Two-body central force problem, Hamilton's principle, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian equations of motion, variational methods, small oscillations, classical fields.

PHY831.name: Statistical Mechanics
PHY831.description: Equilibrium statistical mechanics and thermodynamics. Boltzmann transport equations and hydrodynamics. Brownian and Langevin motion.

PHY841.name: Classical Electrodynamics I
PHY841.description: Electrostatics, magnetostatics, time-varying fields and Maxwell's equations. Gauge transformations. Poynting's theorem and conservation laws.

PHY842.name: Classical Electrodynamics II
PHY842.description: Plane electromagnetic waves, polarization states, reflection, refraction. Wave guides and resonant cavities. Radiating systems, dipole fields, radiated power. Special theory of relativity.

PHY850.name: Electrodynamics of Plasmas
PHY850.description: Plasma kinetic and macroscopic plasma transport theory. Electromagnetic wave propagation and charged particle diffusion processes in plasma. Electromagnetic energy absorption via elastic and inelastic collisions. Dc, rf, and microwave discharges.

PHY851.name: Quantum Mechanics I
PHY851.description: Axioms of quantum and wave mechanics, applications to spherically symmetric potentials. Hydrogen atom, harmonic oscillator, matrix mechanics, angular momentum theory, rotations.
PHY851.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the College of Engineering or College of Natural Science.

PHY852.name: Quantum Mechanics II
PHY852.description: Approximation methods, perturbation theory, atomic physics applications, scattering theory, identical particles, Pauli principle, Bose and Einstein statistics, Hartree-Fock approximation, collisions of identical particles, radiation.

PHY855.name: Quantum Field Theory
PHY855.description: Introduction to field theory as it pertains to numerous problems in particle, nuclear and condensed matter physics. Second quantization, applications to different fields based on perturbation theory. Offered first half of semester.
PHY855.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy or approval of department.

PHY861.name: Beam Physics
PHY861.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

PHY862.name: Accelerator Systems
PHY862.description: Introduction to large accelerator systems, including the physics and engineering of accelerators and key components of accelerators.
PHY862.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Engineering or in the College of Natural Science.

PHY863.name: Special Topics in Accelerator Physics
PHY863.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy or approval of department.

PHY864.name: Accelerator Technology
PHY864.description: Key technologies for modern accelerators such as magnets, the normal conducting and super conducting radio frequency cavities, charged particle sources, diagnostic instruments.
PHY864.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Engineering or in the College of Natural Science.

PHY899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

PHY905.restrictions: Open only to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy.

PHY910.name: Quantum Fluids
PHY910.description: Theory and phenomenology of Bose Einstein condensates, superconductivity and superfluidity.
PHY910.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy or approval of department.

PHY913.name: Foundations of Nanoscience and Nanotechnology
PHY913.description: The self-assembly process and unusual phenomena occurring in nanostructures of carbon. Magnetic aggregates in different size ranges. Finite size and low-dimension effects. Fractional conductance quantization. Response in nanostructures to mechanical stress, high temperature, and electric fields. Offered first half of semester.

PHY918.name: Quantum and Non-linear Optics
PHY918.description: Interaction of light with atoms and semiconductors. Theory and experimental techniques for non-linear optics.
PHY918.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy or approval of department.

PHY919.name: Modern Electronic Structure Theory
PHY919.description: Electronic structure theory using modern computational methods
PHY919.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy or approval of department.

PHY921.name: Quantum Transport and Mesoscopic Physics
PHY921.description: Quantum properties of mesoscopic systems. Quantum dots and large molecules and complex materials. Linear response theory for finite systems.
PHY921.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy or approval of department.

PHY922.name: Ultrafast Phenomena
PHY922.description: Theoretical and experimental tools for addressing ultrafast phenomena, such as femtoscopic lasers
PHY922.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy or approval of department.

PHY925.name: Topics in Molecular and Biophysics
PHY925.description: Advanced topics in molecular and biophysics.
PHY925.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the College of Natural Science or approval of department.

PHY950.name: Data Analysis Methods for High-Energy and Nuclear Physics
PHY950.description: Tools and methods used for analyzing data in large experiments.
PHY950.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy or approval of department.

PHY951.name: Concepts and Calculations for the Standard Model
PHY951.description: Concepts, phenomena and calculations the standard model for particle physics
PHY951.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy or approval of department.

PHY955.name: Relativistic Quantum Field Theory
PHY955.description: Theory of relativistic quantum fields and renormalization with emphasis on applications for particle physics. Offered second half of semester.
PHY955.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy or approval of department.

PHY956.name: Collider Phenomenology
PHY956.description: Theory and phenomenology of high-energy collider physics. Quantum chromo dynamics evolution, structure functions and higher-order calculations.
PHY956.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Physics Major or approval of department.

PHY959.name: Special Topics in High-Energy Physics
PHY959.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy or approval of department.

PHY961.name: Non-Linear Beam Dynamics
PHY961.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year

PHY962.name: Particle Accelerators

PHY973.name: Special Topics in Condensed Matter Physics
PHY973.description: Topics vary and may include quantum optics, scattering methods and Green's functions.

PHY981.name: Nuclear Structure
PHY981.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PHY981.description: Nuclear forces, nuclear matter, nuclear-structure models, few-nucleon systems, electromagnetic and weak transitions.

PHY982.name: Nuclear Dynamics
PHY982.description: Scattering theory, resonance reactions, compound nuclear decay and fission, direct and breakup reactions, time-dependent Hartree-Fock, Vlasov equation, nuclear transport equations, particle production, nuclear liquid-gas phase transition, quark-gluon plasma. Offered second half of semester.
PHY982.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy.

PHY983.name: Nuclear Astrophysics
PHY983.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
PHY983.description: Low energy reaction theory, survey of astrophysics, physics of nuclei and reaction relevant to astrophysics, nuclear reaction rates in stellar environments, stellar evolution, solar neutrinos, big bang nucleosynthesis, dark matter, supernova explosions, r-process, hot CNO and rp-process, cosmochronology

PHY989.name: Special Topics in Nuclear Physics
PHY989.description: Topics in nuclear physics not covered in regularly scheduled courses
PHY989.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Physics and Astronomy or approval of department.

PHY999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
PHY999.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Physics major.
